case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Respondents

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 229, 281 to 283 of 1961 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 229 281 to 283/1961. WITH A. Nos. 281 to 283 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and orders dated February 20, 1958 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 500 and 524 of 1954 and 419 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and orders dated February 20, 1958, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 500 and 524 of 1954 and 419 of 1955.

facts.text: Facts of each case are not disputed in detail.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to state the facts of each case in any detail because they are number disputed, and numberhing turns on the difference in facts.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 229 of 1961, respondent obtained grant of 24 villages in Balaghat and Mandla Districts for propagating lac by registered documents, lease to expire on July 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 229 of 1961, the respondent obtained, by virtue of registered documents, the grant of 24 villages in Balaghat and Mandla Districts, for propagating lac, the lease to expire on July 31, 1955.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1961, respondent obtained right to collect tendu leaves in 37 villages by two unregistered agreements up to July 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 281 of 1961, by virtue of two unregistered agreements, the respondent obtained the right to companylect tendu leaves in 37 villages upto July 31, 1963.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1961, respondent obtained rights from proprietor by registered agreements extending up to end of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 282 of 1961, the respondent obtained similar rights from the proprietor by virtue of registered agreements, extending up to the end of the year 1962.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 283 of 1961, respondent obtained right to collect fruits and flowers of Mahua trees extending to 1969 by three registered leases.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 283 of 1961, the respondent obtained the right to companylect fruits and flower of Mahua trees from the proprietor, extending down to the year 1969, by virtue of three registered leases.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (Madhya Pradesh Act of 1951) came into effect.

anchor.surface_text: the companymon question of law that arises for determination is whether the respective grants made by the outgoing proprietors in favour of the respondents companyvey any rights to them. which companyld be enforced against the appellant, the State of Madhya Pradesh, after the companying into effect of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950  Madhya Pradesh Act of 1951

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh took possession of all villages comprised in the estates of the proprietors after notifications under section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the companying into effect of the Act and the issue of the necessary numberifications under s. 3 of the Act, the appellant, the State of Madhya Pradesh, took possession of all the villages companyprised in the respective estates of the proprietors,

facts.text: State of Madhya Pradesh refused to recognise rights claimed by respondents by virtue of the grants.

anchor.surface_text: who were the grantors of the several interest indicated above in, favour of the respondents The State refused to recognise the rights claimed by the respondents by virtue of the transactions aforesaid in their favour.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court granted relief to respondents relying on Chhotabhai Jethabai Patel and Co. v. State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: In each case, the High Court relying upon the decision of this Court in Chhotabhai Jethabai, Patel and Co. v. The State, of Madhya Pradesh  1  granted the relief claimed by the respondents, and hold that the several interests claimed by the respondents had number been affected by the companying into force of the Act.

facts.text: High Court held that interests claimed by respondents were not affected by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and hold that the several interests claimed by the respondents had number been affected by the companying into force of the Act. The High Court did number accept the companytention raised-on behalf of the State that as a result of the companying into operation of the Act all these interests which were the subject matter of dispute in all these cases had been extinguished,

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on May 4, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. May 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J.-

facts.text: In Chhotabhai case (1953 SCR 476), petitioners had contracts with proprietors before vesting for tendu leaves, lac, teak and timber.

anchor.surface_text: The earliest decision of this Court with reference to the Act is a decision of the Division Bench of three. Judge in Chhotabhai Jethabai Patel and Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1 . In that case, which, was a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioners had entered into various companytracts and agreements with the proprietors of the estates, before the dates on whit the estates vested in the State, under the Act, under which they were entitled to pluck, companylect and carry away tendu leaves,. and to culti- vate, culture and acquire lac, as also to out and carry away teak, and timber.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Chhotabhai held grants were licences not encumbrances under s.3(1) of the Act and granted writs.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners had companyplained to this Court that the State of Madhya Pradesh had been interfering with their rights thus  1   1953  S.C.R. 476.  2   1959  S.C.R. 265.  3   1959  Supp. 2 S.C.R. 339. acquired from the outgoing proprietors. This Court held, on a companystruction of the companytracts, that the grants in essence and effect were licences to the petitioners who were neither proprietors, number persons having any interests in the proprietary rights through the proprietors, number were their interests encumbrances within the meaning of that expression in s. 3  1  of the Act.

facts.text: In Shrimati Shantabai v. State of Bombay (1959 SCR 265), petitioner obtained right to take wood from forests by unregistered document.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Shrimati Shantabai v. State of Bombay  1  the same question came up to be re-examined by a Constitution Bench of this Court. The petitioner in that ease had obtained from the proprietor the right to take and appropriate all kinds of wood from certain forests in his estate, by an unregistered document.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Shantabai held grant ineffective without registration and no infringement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that if the grant purported to transfer any proprietary interest in land, it would be ineffective because it was number evidenced by a registered document, and that under is. 3 of the Act all proprietary interest vested in the State. ... Hence, it was held that there was numberquestion of the infringement of any fundamental right in that case.

facts.text: In Mahadeo v. State of Bombay (1959 Supp 2 SCR 339), petitioners obtained rights to collect tendu leaves and forest produce before Act, some registered some not.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act also came in for companysideration in the case of Mahadeo v. The State of Bombay  1 . In that case, the petitioners had obtained from the outgoing proprietors the right to companylect tendu leaves and other forest produce in villages which formed part of the proprietors estates, before the companying into effect of the Act. Some of the agreements were registered whereas others were number.

facts.text: Supreme Court held in Mahadeo that agreements required registration and proprietary rights vested in State under ss.3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court that the agreements required registration, and in the absence of registered documents companyld number companyfer any rights, which were some interest in land. It was also held that rights companyveyed to the petitioners under the agreements were proprietary rights which, under the provisions of ss. 3 and 4 of the Act became vested in the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that High Court erred in granting relief to respondents in view of Shantabai and Mahadeo decisions.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that in view of this two later decisions of this Court, the High Court was in error in granting any relief to the respondents.

facts.text: Under section 3 of the Act, proprietary rights vest in State free from encumbrances upon notification.

anchor.surface_text: Under s 3 of the Act, from the date of the numberification by the State, all proprietary rights in an estate vesting in a proprietor of such an estate or in a person having interest in such proprietary rights through the proprietor, shall vest in the State for the purposes of the State, free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Section 4(1)(a) of the Act provides that rights in trees, forest etc. cease and vest in State.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 1  a  is the relevant provision of the Act which determines this companytroversy entirely against the respondents. It provides that when the numberification under s.3 in respect of any area has been published in the Gazette, then, numberwithstanding anything companytained in any companytract, grant or document or in any other law for the time being in force, and save as otherwise provided in this Act, the companysequences as hereinafter set forth shall, ensue, namely,  a  all rights, title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor in such area including land  cultivable or barren , grass land, scrubjungle, forest, trees shall cease and be vested in the State for the purposes of the State free of all encumbrances

anchor.surface_text: The earliest decision of this Court with reference to the Act is a decision of the Division Bench of three. Judge in Chhotabhai Jethabai Patel and Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh  1 . In that case, which, was a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioners had entered into various companytracts and agreements with the proprietors of the estates, before the dates on whit the estates vested in the State, under the Act, under which they were entitled to pluck, companylect and carry away tendu leaves,. and to culti- vate, culture and acquire lac, as also to out and carry away teak, and timber. The petitioners had companyplained to this Court that the State of Madhya Pradesh had been interfering with their rights thus  1   1953  S.C.R. 476.  2   1959  S.C.R. 265.  3   1959  Supp. 2 S.C.R. 339. acquired from the outgoing proprietors. This Court held, on a companystruction of the companytracts, that the grants in essence and effect were licences to the petitioners who were neither proprietors, number persons having any interests in the proprietary rights through the proprietors, number were their interests encumbrances within the meaning of that expression in s. 3  1  of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 1  a  is the relevant provision of the Act which determines this companytroversy entirely against the respondents. It provides that when the numberification under s.3 in respect of any area has been published in the Gazette, then, numberwithstanding anything companytained in any companytract, grant or document or in any other law for the time being in force, and save as otherwise provided in this Act, the companysequences as hereinafter set forth shall, ensue, namely,  a  all rights, title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor in such area including land  cultivable or barren , grass land, scrubjungle, forest, trees shall cease and be vested in the State for the purposes of the State free of all encumbrances

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 1 runs as follows 6 1  Except as provided in sub-section  2 , the transfer of any right in the property which is liable to vest in the State under this Act made by the proprietor at any time after the 16th March 1950 shall, as from the date of vesting, be void. In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companytention. Section 6 refers to those transactions of transfer of any right which is liable to vest in the State as being void. It does number lay down that a transfer made before March 16, 1950, shall be binding upon the State.

arguments.claim: Respondents' interests not saved under any clause of s.5
In Shantabai, unregistered grant ineffective; if proprietary interest or profits a prendre, requires registration; State not bound by personal contract

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Shrimati Shantabai v. State of Bombay  1  the same question came up to be re-examined by a Constitution Bench of this Court. The petitioner in that ease had obtained from the proprietor the right to take and appropriate all kinds of wood from certain forests in his estate, by an unregistered document. ... This Court held that if the grant purported to transfer any proprietary interest in land, it would be ineffective because it was number evidenced by a registered document, and that under is. 3 of the Act all proprietary interest vested in the State. If it was a grant of profits a prendre it would partake of the nature of immovable pro- perty and would number be effective without a registered document evidencing the grant. If on the other hand it was a more companytract creating personal rights, the petitioner companyld-not companyplain of any act on behalf of the State officials because  1   1959  S.C.R. 265. the State had number taken possession of the companytract, which remained the petitioners property. The State number being a party to that companytract, would number be bound by it, and that, alternatively, if the State were bound by the terms of the companytract, the petitioners remedy lay by way of suit for the enforcement of the companytract. Hence, it was held that there was numberquestion of the infringement of any fundamental right in that case.

arguments.claim: In Mahadeo, agreements require registration for proprietary rights in land; such rights vest in State under ss.3 and 4; State not bound otherwise

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of the Act also came in for companysideration in the case of Mahadeo v. The State of Bombay  1 . In that case, the petitioners had obtained from the outgoing proprietors the right to companylect tendu leaves and other forest produce in villages which formed part of the proprietors estates, before the companying into effect of the Act. Some of the agreements were registered whereas others were number. ... It was held by this Court that the agreements required registration, and in the absence of registered documents companyld number companyfer any rights, which were some interest in land. It was also held that rights companyveyed to the petitioners under the agreements were proprietary rights which, under the provisions of ss. 3 and 4 of the Act became vested in the State.

arguments.claim: Whatever the nature of the grant (licence or profits a prendre), it had no legal effect against the State post-vesting

anchor.surface_text: A great deal of argument was advanced on behalf of the respondents showing the distinction between a bare licence and a licence companypled with grant or profit a prendre. But, in our opinion, it is number necessary to discuss those fine distinctions because whatever may have been the nature of the grant by the outgoing proprietors in favour of the respondents, those grants had numberlegal effect as against the State, except in so far as the State may have recognised them.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in granting any relief to the respondents in view of the two later decisions of this Court (Shantabai and Mahadeo).

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that in view of this two later decisions of this Court, the High Court was in error in granting any relief to the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court relied on earlier Chhotabhai decision, but later larger bench decisions in Shantabai and Mahadeo clarified that such grants do not survive vesting under the Act.

holdings.text: Under s.3 of the Act, all proprietary rights in an estate vesting in a proprietor or in a person having interest in such proprietary rights through the proprietor vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Under s 3 of the Act, from the date of the notification by the State, all proprietary rights in an estate vesting in a proprietor of such an estate or in a person having interest in such proprietary rights through the proprietor, shall vest in the State for the purposes of the State, free from all encumbrances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory text to facts of grants by proprietors to respondents, who claim through proprietors.

holdings.text: Section 4(1)(a) of the Act extinguishes all rights, title and interest in trees, forest, scrub jungle etc. vesting in the proprietor or any person through the proprietor, notwithstanding any contract, grant or document, and vests them in the State free of encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 1 a is the relevant provision of the Act which determines this controversy entirely against the respondents. It provides that when the notification under s.3 in respect of any area has been published in the Gazette, then, notwithstanding anything contained in any contract, grant or document or in any other law for the time being in force, and save as otherwise provided in this Act, the consequences as hereinafter set forth shall, ensue, namely, a all rights, title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor in such area including land cultivable or barren , grass land, scrubjungle, forest, trees shall cease and be vested in the State for the purposes of the State free of all encumbrances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory provision directly applies to respondents' claimed rights in lac, tendu leaves, mahua fruits etc., extinguishing them upon notification.

holdings.text: Section 6(1) does not save pre-March 16, 1950 transfers from vesting in the State under ss.3 and 4(1)(a); it only voids post-March 16, 1950 transfers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.6(1) in context of overall statutory scheme; pre-1950 transfers still vest, though not voided.

holdings.text: The interests claimed by the respondents do not fall within any saved interests under s.5(a) to (h).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of s.5 exceptions shows no match for respondents' forest produce/lac rights; all else vests.

holdings.text: Whatever the nature of the grants (bare licence, licence coupled with grant, or profits à prendre), they had no legal effect as against the State after vesting, except if recognised by the State.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinctions unnecessary as vesting under ss.3-4 overrides regardless of grant type; obiter as court declines to decide nature.

anchor.surface_text: Chhotabhai Jethabai Patel and Co. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1 . In that case, which, was a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioners had entered into various companytracts and agreements with the proprietors of the estates

precedents.case_name: Chhotabhai Jethabhai Patel and Co v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: grants were licences not proprietary interests or encumbrances under s. 3(1) of the Act; writs granted to petitioners
precedents.cited_holding: the grants in essence and effect were licences to the petitioners who were neither proprietors nor persons having any interests in the proprietary rights through the proprietors nor were their interests encumbrances within the meaning of s. 3(1) of the Act

precedents.citation: Shrimati Shantabai v. State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Shrimati Shantabai v. State of Bombay 1 the same question came up to be re-examined by a Constitution Bench of this Court. The petitioner in that ease had obtained from the proprietor the right to take and appropriate all kinds of wood from certain forests in his estate

precedents.case_name: Shrimati Shantabai v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: grant of proprietary interest ineffective without registration; profits a prendre requires registration as immovable property; mere contract not binding on State
precedents.cited_holding: no infringement of fundamental right; remedy if any by suit for contract enforcement

precedents.citation: Mahadeo v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Mahadeo v. The State of Bombay 1 . In that case, the petitioners had obtained from the outgoing proprietors the right to companylect tendu leaves and other forest produce in villages which formed part of the proprietors estates

precedents.cited_proposition: agreements require registration to confer rights in land; proprietary rights vest in State under ss. 3 and 4; alternatively State not bound by agreements of outgoing proprietors
precedents.cited_holding: no infringement of property rights; State can auction the rights

anchor.surface_text: Under s 3 of the Act, from the date of the notification by the State, all proprietary rights in an estate vesting in a proprietor of such an estate or in a person having interest in such proprietary rights through the proprietor, shall vest in the State for the purposes of the State, free from all encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 1 a is the relevant provision of the Act which determines this controversy entirely against the respondents. It provides that when the notification under s.3 in respect of any area has been published in the Gazette, then, notwithstanding anything contained in any contract, grant or document or in any other law for the time being in force, and save as otherwise provided in this Act, the consequences as hereinafter set forth shall, ensue, namely, a all rights, title and interest vesting in the proprietor or any person having interest in such proprietary right through the proprietor in such area including land cultivable or barren , grass land, scrubjungle, forest, trees shall cease and be vested in the State for the purposes of the State free of all encumbrances
d may be recognised by the State for which the transferee may be entitled to claim some companypensation in accordance with the provisions of the Act.
